In the context of getting data science work, it’s easy to get caught up in all the cool and exciting technical aspects of data science while virtually ignoring all other non-technical aspects 😅

In the context of getting data science work, it’s easy to get caught up in all the cool and exciting technical aspects of data science while virtually ignoring all other non-technical aspects 😅 

This is the data science version of “all chest, no legs.” 

Although technical skills are absolutely critical, non-technical aspects such as domain knowledge and communication skills are also important 💡 

This is especially true if the hiring manager is non-technical (common at smaller organizations without a dedicated data science team). 

👉 One simple thing that can help your portfolio stand out is listing all the domains in which you’ve worked. 

*** 

What are some other ways one can convey non-technical skills in data science?

Last week I had the pleasure of chatting with author, teacher, and seasoned AI entrepreneur Sinan Ozdemir on Intro.

Last week I had the pleasure of chatting with author, teacher, and seasoned AI entrepreneur Sinan Ozdemir on Intro.

I always get a ton of value in learning from those (way) ahead of me. I find this is for two reasons👇 

1) Talking to someone who’s done what you’re trying to do helps make abstract goals (and dreams) more real 
2) They can challenge assumptions that are likely holding you back 

The latter happened to me last week when I asked Sinan, “Is consulting a good path to building a product?” 

To which he said, “No.” 😮

The takeaway was that if you want to build a product, build a product. 

Consulting can be used as a way to survive, but it is not the best path to an MVP 🚀 

I think this shift in my perspective could have just saved me 1-2 years of going down the wrong rabbit hole 😅 Thanks Sinan!

#entrepreneurship #MVP #consulting #datascience

Here’s how I’d learn AI in 2025 (if I could start over)…

Here’s how I’d learn AI in 2025 (if I could start over)… 

First, I’d familiarize myself with modern AI tools like ChatGPT and Claude. 

This would give me a practical understanding of what these models can do and how to use them. Second, I’d install Python on my machine. 

While you can go far with no-code tools today, these can’t easily be used to build custom AI solutions or process data in bulk. 

Third, I’d build my first automation using Python and an LLM. 

My approach would be to pick a task that I frequently use ChatGPT for and then try and implement it with OpenAI’s Python API 

After I build a few of these types of automations, I’d next build a machine learning project. 

This would consist of training a model or doing a traditional NLP project. 

Finally, I’d find a real-world problem I could solve using my new AI skills. 

To do that, I try any of the following: 

1. Reach out to business owners and professionals in my network 
2. Join a research group at my University (if I was a student) 
3. Find an internship (if I was a student) 
4. Find a freelance gig on Upwork 

I talk more about this 5-step approach in a recent YouTube video… 

Check it out: https://lnkd.in/g2VqHxZX

This is why we can’t have nice things 😂

This is why we can’t have nice things 😂 

The “Hammer Problem” captures a bias we (i.e. humans) have when it comes to building AI solutions.

We are drawn toward a technology-first rather than a problem-first approach 🔨

A (much) better way is to start with the problem because in business, solving problems = generating value 💸 

👉 Since we don’t get bonus points for using AI to solve our problems, we should seek the cheapest, quickest to implement, and most reliable solutions.

Statistics is fundamental to data science, but that’s not all it’s good for.

Statistics is fundamental to data science, but that’s not all it’s good for. 

Here are 3 statistics principles that improved my decision-making 👇  

1) Expectations Values 🤔 

When weighing outcomes, it’s not just about the probability of success but also the potential upside and downside of each. 

Even if something has a low probability of success, it can still be the right call if it has a huge upside and little downside. 

2) Population Thinking 🧠 

While summary metrics (e.g., mean, standard deviation, and accuracy) are widely used in business, they don’t tell the whole story. 

Behind every summary is a wide range of possibilities (i.e. a distribution). Remembering this is important.

3) “All models are wrong (some are useful)” ❌ 

We all have internal models of the world that we use to make decisions. 

Never questioning these models keeps people stuck and leads to poor decision-making.

Content creation saved my life…

Content creation saved my life… 

Here’s why. 

18 months ago, I left my (well-paying) data science role to pursue entrepreneurship full-time. 

15 months in, I still hadn’t come close to making back my full-time income and was on my LAST month of runway 😅 

But then something saved me… 

I launched a course on Maven that earned my first $10k month (entirely from self-employment income). 

And there was one key reason behind this… content creation. 

70% of people who signed up for the course had heard of me through my content (and most of those were from a single article). 

I say all this because there are so many upsides to content creation for technical professionals and entrepreneurs, but they don’t do it… 

… and I want to understand why. 

What’s your biggest obstacle in hitting “post”? (No wrong answers)

Despite the hype, AI agents are the next natural step of AI systems (IMO)

Despite the hype, AI agents are the next natural step of AI systems (IMO)

This is for one simple reason: test-time compute 🧠 

The breakthrough that unlocked systems like ChatGPT was train-time compute.

i.e. bigger models + more data + more compute = better performance

However, over the past several months, we’ve seen another breakthrough with test-time compute.

The basic formula here is: more inference tokens = better performance.

This has been the driving force behind the rise of AI agents, and I don’t see them going away anytime soon.

That is why (for the first time ever) I’ve updated the syllabus for my AI Builders cohort to incorporate practical examples of building AI agents.

Check out the course details here: https://lnkd.in/gPHZTdWs

P.S. The price will be increasing from $700 to $850 on April 4th, so snag a spot now at the discounted price :)

Breaking down my first $10k month (as an entrepreneur)

Breaking down my first $10k month (as an entrepreneur)

14 months after leaving my full-time job, I was still living off savings...

But that (finally) changed in month 15. Here’s what kept me alive:

1) AI Builders Bootcamp: $9,265.48
2) Medium (blog): $894.52
3) YouTube: $542.73
4) Consulting calls: $363.21
Total: $10,826.72

I don’t share this as a flex (wouldn’t be that impressive anyway 😅) but rather to share the reality of being fully self-employed.

It took me 15 months of failure and volatility to match my full-time income.

With that said, however, these past couple of years have been the most fulfilling ones of my life, which is worth more to me than any salary.

AI Agents present a new way of thinking about software...

AI Agents present a new way of thinking about software...

Rather than explicitly defining rules and business logic, agents involve giving LLMs the tools they need to solve problems.

For example, instead of developing a rule-based customer support bot, you might give an LLM... 

1. Context about your company
2. A search tool for support docs
3. The ability to escalate issues

With today's powerful LLMs fine-tuned for function calling, such a naive system can get you much of the way there out of the box.

In a new blog post, I explain how LLM tool-use works under the hood and build a simple YouTube video agent using OpenAI's new Agents SDK.

Power laws (e.g. Pareto distributions) break many of our favorite statistical tools.

Power laws (e.g. Pareto distributions) break many of our favorite statistical tools. 

While awareness can help us avoid these problems, it is not always clear what distribution some given data follow in practice. 

In my latest blog, I describe how to objectively detect Power Laws from real-world data using Python 🐍 

I use this method to determine whether the following quantities "truly" fit a Power Law distribution 👇 

👀 LinkedIn Impressions 
📰 Monthly Followers gained on Medium 
💰YouTube Video Earnings 

Thanks to Towards Data Science for publishing this most recent series

I couldn’t get a data science job until I did these 3 things.

I couldn’t get a data science job until I did these 3 things.

👇 

1) Reframe resume

The goal of a resume isn’t to get a job—it’s to get an interview. No need to include every little experience, project, or award. 

The more fluff in a resume, the less attention is left for the things that matter. 

2) Make a portfolio

Although it’s never been easier to make a portfolio website, most people still don’t make one. 

This was one of the things the hiring manager for my last job said stood out to him. 

3) Stay out of the weeds 

As a technical person, my default response to every interview question went straight into the details. 

However, I eventually learned to explain things simply and then get into the weeds if people ask about it. 

If you're struggling with your portfolio, I share a video in the comments showing a free, no-code way to make one with GitHub Pages 😁

Matías 4X'ed his Upwork leads by rewriting his profile to be **client-focused**

Matías 4X'ed his Upwork leads by rewriting his profile to be **client-focused**

This inspired me to build an LLM system to optimize my profile too...

It's been 3 years since I last used Upwork.

Looking back at my profile, it's amazing that anyone ever hired me, because my profile is so bad 😅

That's why I recently built an AI copywriter to rewrite my profile using the "Evaluator-Optimizer" agent design pattern.

Here's how it works:

1. Input profile
2. Profile is evaluated via a rule-based test suite
3. If tests are passed, break out of the loop
4. Test results are translated into a prompt to rewrite profile
5. Profile is rewritten
6. Repeat from Step 2

The example code is freely available on GitHub, and I reviewed it in the blog post linked below :)

👉 Blog post: https://lnkd.in/d9x5Z325

What is the difference between Principal Component Analysis (PCA) and Independent Component Analysis (ICA)? 🤔

What is the difference between Principal Component Analysis (PCA) and Independent Component Analysis (ICA)? 🤔 

Although the two approaches may seem related, they perform different tasks. 

👉 PCA is used to compress information (i.e. dimensionality reduction) 

👉 While ICA separates information by transforming the input space into a maximally independent basis.

5 AI Projects You Can Build In 60 Minutes (or less)

5 AI Projects You Can Build In 60 Minutes (or less)

The most practical AI use case for developers is using an LLM as a coding assistant.

With tools like ChatGPT, Cursor, and Co-pilot, projects that used to take days now take hours.

Here are 5 AI project ideas you can build in under an hour 👇

1) PDF Summarization Tool

Extract text from a PDF and have your favorite LLM summarize it for you.

2) Clustering Customer Reviews

Translate customer reviews into text embeddings and apply a traditional clustering algorithm to it (e.g., KMeans).

3) Document QA Chatbot

Extract the text from a PDF and ask questions about it to a long context LLM.

4) Sentiment Analysis of YouTube Comments

Use the youtube-comment-downloader Python lib to get comments from a YouTube video then pass them through a sentiment classification model from the Hugging Face hub.

5) Gmail Inbox Categorization

Extract your Gmail inbox, translate each email into a vector, and perform clustering similarly to project idea 2.


Let me know which one you’re curious about, and I’ll share more resources to help you get started :)

1) Start with a side hustle

A side hustle is a great, low-stakes way to develop the necessary skillset.

However, when you focus on solving problems, there are very few constraints on how you can generate value, so you can make a living on your terms.

When you read the word “value” what comes to mind? 🤔

When you read the word “value” what comes to mind? 🤔

You might think money 💸

Money has value, and its value is clear-cut.

$1 can get a cheeseburger 🍔
$10 can get a book 📕
$100 can get a new pair of Nikes 👟

While this may seem innocuous, I believe the strong association between value and money has broader negative impacts ☄️

When making (value) decisions, people often (unconsciously) give too much weight to money.

👉 I call this the “Value Heuristic”

Value decisions are hard, so our brains try to use shortcuts to make them.

This might save time and energy, but it often leads people to make decisions not fully aligned with their true values.

For example, taking a well-paying job you don’t like over a low-paying job you love 🫤💵 > 😁

This is why it is critical to know your values.

They give you a lens through which you can evaluate decisions.

Imbalanced data presents a challenge in machine learning when one class label occurs much less frequently than another.

Imbalanced data presents a challenge in machine learning when one class label occurs much less frequently than another. 

For instance, training a model to differentiate between sick and healthy patients might have only 1% sick patients in the data 🤕 

The common issue is that classifiers trained on imbalanced data tend to “over-predict” the majority class, resulting in high accuracy 📈 but poor performance on the minority class 📉 

One approach to address this is resampling the data to balance it, either by oversampling the minority class or undersampling the majority class ⚖️ 

However, this may lead to a mismatch between the training data distribution and the real-world distribution. 

An alternative solution is Cost-Sensitive Learning, which involves weighting different misclassification errors based on their real-world costs 💰 

By incorporating the real-world costs of false positives and false negatives in model development, this technique can overcome the imbalanced data problem without altering the training data distribution. 

To explore this further, there is a great paper on the topic by 
Charles X. Ling and Victor S. Sheng. 

*** 

Any thoughts on Cost-Sensitive Learning compared to other techniques for handling imbalanced data?

If you are interested in decision-making or risk-taking in the real world, I highly recommend this book.

If you are interested in decision-making or risk-taking in the real world, I highly recommend this book. 

The Black Swan by Nassim Nicholas Taleb is one of those books that changed how I view the world 👀 

It describes how much of the world around us is driven by low-probability, high-impact events called Black Swans.

One of my big takeaways from this book is a strategy for decision-making in Black Swan environments called the Barbell Strategy 🏋️

This is essentially an 80-20 approach to resource allocation, where 80% of the resources are put toward a “very safe bet” while the remaining 20% are put toward a “very risky bet”.

Here are a few examples 👇 

- 80% of portfolio in T-bills, 20% in stocks 
- 80% of income comes from salary, 20% from side-hustle 
- 80% of time is spent using skills, 20% of time is spent learning new ones 

What are some other places one could use this 80-20 strategy? 🤔

While using an existing LLM off-the-shelf (e.g. ChatGPT) is great for a wide breadth of use cases, there are situations where this doesn't cut it.

While using an existing LLM off-the-shelf (e.g. ChatGPT) is great for a wide breadth of use cases, there are situations where this doesn't cut it.

For these cases, model fine-tuning can help 🔧 

This is where you take an existing LLM and adapt it for a particular use case.

🔑 One of the key upsides to model fine-tuning is that a smaller fine-tuned model (e.g. InstructGPT) can often outperform a larger pre-trained model (e.g. GPT-3)

I provide a complete (beginner-friendly) guide to model fine-tuning in my latest YouTube video.

Getting a Data Science Job was hard until I learned these 5 things 👇

Getting a Data Science Job was hard until I learned these 5 things 👇  

1. Adapt your resume to the specific role

You have about 7 seconds of a hiring manager's attention when reviewing your resume; use it to call out all the skills they listed in the job description.

2. Do real-world projects

While toy projects from class or Kaggle are a great way to learn, hiring managers care about real-world impact.

3. Make a portfolio 

Despite the free no-code tools for making a portfolio website, most people don't make one. That makes this a super easy way to stand out.

4. Stay out of the weeds (unless they ask) 

This was one of my greatest struggles. When someone asked about a project, I would dive right into the technical details. This is the best way to lose someone's attention (even data scientists).

5. Be yourself (not who you think they want to hire)

When I interviewed for my full-time data science role, I dove into a rant about my love for optimization. Most people get confused and awkward when I discuss such topics, but not the interviewers. They got pumped up... that's when I knew I found my people 😁 

What was an unlock for you when applying to data science roles?

Although ChatGPT (and friends) has captured the world’s imagination regarding AI, the business value of building an "AI chatbot" may not justify the cost. 

Here are 5 better LLM use cases for business 👇 

1) Structure unstructured data—format data from inconvenient sources into a structured database 

2) Standardize data—resolve conflicts between databases and make it analytics-ready 

3) Data augmentation—enrich existing datasets with meta-tags and other information 

4) Data generation—create synthetic datasets for developing custom AI solutions 

5) Semantic search—improve existing search functions using text embeddings
